description: Citrix XenServer is the free virtualization software from Citrix. It is a commercially backed implementation of the open source Xen virtualization platform. The low cost of entry makes XenServer an attractive option for small and medium businesses looking for advanced hypervisor functions (clustering, live migration, centralized management) without the large price tag associated with competing products.

>> All right, well we'll go ahead and
wrap it up right here.

1596
01:22:19,560 --> 01:22:22,000
We do have a bit to go through but
this will be all for now.

1597
01:22:22,000 --> 01:22:24,600
If you ever have any
questions during the show,

1598
01:22:24,600 --> 01:22:28,100
right below our live page we have

1599

Go ahead, type stuff in there, blow it up.

1600
01:22:30,120 --> 01:22:33,080
We got a little monitor here we

1601
01:22:33,080 --> 01:22:36,900
If you ever have any questions after
the show, you can jump into the Q and

1602
01:22:36,900 --> 01:22:39,470
A section at the top of every webpage.

1603
01:22:40,820 --> 01:22:44,610
Jump into the forums and

1604
01:22:44,610 --> 01:22:47,940
And if you're ever away from your PC you

1605
01:22:47,940 --> 01:22:52,770
we've got a channel up there and

1606
01:22:52,770 --> 01:22:56,300
All right, well signing out for
ITProTV, I'm Nathan Copeland.

1607
01:22:56,300 --> 01:22:56,900
>> And I'm Ronnie Wong.

episodes.title: Advanced Configuration
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:30,503 --> 00:00:33,297
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

3
00:00:33,297 --> 00:00:35,171
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

4
00:00:35,171 --> 00:00:35,671
I'm your host, Don Pezet.

5
00:00:36,900 --> 00:00:40,140
Today back with another
episode of XenServer.

6
00:00:40,140 --> 00:00:42,009
This is one of our special shows, and

7
00:00:42,009 --> 00:00:45,264
we're not actually lining up with
a sort of vacation this time,

8
00:00:45,264 --> 00:00:48,876
we're just covering a really cool
technology to help make you aware.

9
00:00:48,876 --> 00:00:54,200
XenServer, as we talked about in the first
episode, is a free of charge product

10
00:00:54,200 --> 00:00:58,720
from Citrix they charge for support of
course, but the product itself is free.

11
00:00:58,720 --> 00:01:01,250
And that makes it really
attractive to small and

12
00:01:01,250 --> 00:01:04,220
medium businesses that are looking
to get into virtualization.

13
00:01:04,220 --> 00:01:08,270
Without the huge price hit that you
get with something like VMware.

14
00:01:08,270 --> 00:01:12,700
Now Ronnie and Nate in the first episode
showed you guys how to install ZenServer.

15
00:01:12,700 --> 00:01:16,170
And you got your first glimpse at getting
a virtual machine up and running.

16
00:01:16,170 --> 00:01:20,310
They brought up a Windows machine,
and they threw the xen-tools

17
00:01:20,310 --> 00:01:24,120
on there to get it nice and working
happy inside of the Xen environment.

18
00:01:24,120 --> 00:01:27,950
Today what I'm gonna do is I'm gonna show
you the same thing but with a Linux host.

19
00:01:27,950 --> 00:01:29,770
We'll get that fired up and going.

20
00:01:29,770 --> 00:01:32,720
And then we'll show some advanced
configuration that we might want to do

21
00:01:32,720 --> 00:01:36,080
on our virtual machines just to keep
our environment running smoothly.

22
00:01:36,080 --> 00:01:38,400
and take advantage of some
of the cooler features.

23
00:01:38,400 --> 00:01:40,920
And we should have plenty
of time this episode.

24
00:01:40,920 --> 00:01:44,590
I want to do a quick
example of clustering also

25
00:01:44,590 --> 00:01:47,890
to cluster a couple of XenServers
together for high-availability purposes.

26
00:01:47,890 --> 00:01:49,320
So really, really cool stuff.

27
00:01:49,320 --> 00:01:52,000
That's what we're shooting for
here in this episode.

28
00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:54,640
So let's go ahead and get started.

29
00:01:54,640 --> 00:01:58,130
First thing I wanna do is, you guys got
a chance to see installing a Windows

30
00:01:58,130 --> 00:02:02,210
machine, and so what they did is
they create a virtual machine, and

31
00:02:02,210 --> 00:02:06,730
they told it they wanted to install an
operating system from a Windows ISO image.

32
00:02:06,730 --> 00:02:10,160
Well I've done the exact
same thing except for Linux.

33
00:02:10,160 --> 00:02:16,210
I've got my ISO library here and
I grabbed a CentOS 6.5 installer DVD.

34
00:02:16,210 --> 00:02:17,720
So I've just got that there.

35
00:02:17,720 --> 00:02:19,510
And I created a new virtual machine but

36
00:02:19,510 --> 00:02:22,200
instead of choosing Windows,
I chose Linux, right?

37
00:02:22,200 --> 00:02:23,760
Easy enough to do.

38
00:02:23,760 --> 00:02:26,468
Even easier if you worry
about security at all.

39
00:02:26,468 --> 00:02:28,120
But [LAUGH] so,

40
00:02:28,120 --> 00:02:32,100
if we go to create a new virtual machine,
you 'll see all our various options and

41
00:02:32,100 --> 00:02:36,360
the Windows stuff is listed first because
Citirx, they know that their market is.

42
00:02:36,360 --> 00:02:40,330
But if you go down a little further,
you'll start to see CentOS, Debian,

43
00:02:40,330 --> 00:02:43,680
Oracle Enterprise, Linux,
Red Hat and so on.

44
00:02:43,680 --> 00:02:45,110
You pick the appropriate one.

45
00:02:45,110 --> 00:02:48,350
Now the version numbers here
are a little bit specific.

46
00:02:48,350 --> 00:02:51,810
If you got Su -c Linux 11.

47
00:02:51,810 --> 00:02:56,940
And you choose a Su -c Linux 10 template,
it does cause problems.

48
00:02:56,940 --> 00:03:00,470
It's doing various configurations on the
back end to make sure the virtual machine

49
00:03:00,470 --> 00:03:03,600
is set up to work for the version of
the operating system that you have.

50
00:03:03,600 --> 00:03:05,240
So you need to choose the correct one.

51
00:03:05,240 --> 00:03:08,400
Now, if your operating
system is not in the list,

52
00:03:08,400 --> 00:03:09,920
it doesn't mean you're out of luck.

53
00:03:09,920 --> 00:03:12,550
It just means that Citrix
hasn't fully tested and

54
00:03:12,550 --> 00:03:15,330
certified that OS for your system.

55
00:03:15,330 --> 00:03:19,020
So for example, just yesterday, well,
I guess it depends on when you watch this

56
00:03:19,020 --> 00:03:23,580
episode, but if you're watching it live,
just yesterday CentOS 7 came out.

57
00:03:23,580 --> 00:03:27,350
And if I go up here and look,
I'll see that CentOS 7 is not on my list.

58
00:03:27,350 --> 00:03:29,280
Six is the highest that it goes.

59
00:03:29,280 --> 00:03:31,960
Well does that mean
that I can't run seven?

60
00:03:31,960 --> 00:03:32,580
Maybe.

61
00:03:32,580 --> 00:03:34,390
It may not be compatible
with XenServer yet.

62
00:03:34,390 --> 00:03:38,390
But you can always take a stab at it by
scrolling down to the very bottom and

63
00:03:38,390 --> 00:03:41,210
choosing other install media.

64
00:03:41,210 --> 00:03:42,790
Other install media just means.

65
00:03:42,790 --> 00:03:46,630
Hey lets go with the default options in
XenServer, you can tweak them as needed.

66
00:03:46,630 --> 00:03:49,460
Then you can figure out what it
takes to get that OS up and running.

67
00:03:49,460 --> 00:03:52,550
Really useful, if you're gonna
run something like OpenBSD or

68
00:03:52,550 --> 00:03:58,120
other operating systems that just aren't
on Citrix's radar for support, all right?

69
00:03:58,120 --> 00:04:02,890
But in my case, I'm going CentOS, which
is right here in the supported platforms.

70
00:04:02,890 --> 00:04:06,290
I just need to pick whether it's 32-bit or
64-bit, right?

71
00:04:06,290 --> 00:04:09,490
From there the creation process
is pretty much the same, right?

72
00:04:09,490 --> 00:04:10,980
We just move forward.

73
00:04:10,980 --> 00:04:12,740
And we give it a name.

74
00:04:12,740 --> 00:04:14,520
So this is my Linux machine.

75
00:04:16,870 --> 00:04:19,150
And we tell it where we're
going to install from.

76
00:04:19,150 --> 00:04:23,520
And we could install from a physical
DVD or from a ISO which is what I have.

77
00:04:26,270 --> 00:04:28,600
And we pick which server
it's gonna reside on.

78
00:04:28,600 --> 00:04:30,990
Now, if you've only got one
server you won't see this screen.

79
00:04:30,990 --> 00:04:33,470
In my case I've got two servers
which is why it's asking.

80
00:04:33,470 --> 00:04:37,660
But because of the way I chose he DVD
it's tied to this server right there.

81
00:04:39,070 --> 00:04:41,820
It'll ask for how many CPUs and
how much memory I need.

82
00:04:41,820 --> 00:04:45,232
And that depends on what I'm
plan on using this machine for.

83
00:04:45,232 --> 00:04:48,190
You wanna write size it for
if you're doing a database server or

84
00:04:48,190 --> 00:04:49,740
a web server, or whatever.

85
00:04:49,740 --> 00:04:51,400
We can always come back and
change this later.

86
00:04:51,400 --> 00:04:53,120
I'll show you guys that in a few moments.

87
00:04:55,440 --> 00:04:56,650
Then you pick your storage.

88
00:04:56,650 --> 00:04:57,690
Where it's gonna reside and

89
00:04:57,690 --> 00:05:01,980
you'll see the template here is defaulting
to eight gigabytes for this install.

90
00:05:01,980 --> 00:05:04,960
For a Linux server eight gigabytes
is usually plenty of space and

91
00:05:04,960 --> 00:05:06,450
it's probably enough for us.

92
00:05:06,450 --> 00:05:08,790
If it's not we can change it right here.

93
00:05:08,790 --> 00:05:12,670
You can pull up the properties and
adjust that size and make it bigger.

94
00:05:12,670 --> 00:05:14,670
I dont believe itll
let you make it smaller.

95
00:05:14,670 --> 00:05:17,931
Yeah, it wont let you make it smaller,
but you can make it bigger, and

96
00:05:17,931 --> 00:05:20,069
you can add more than one
hard drive if you want,

97
00:05:20,069 --> 00:05:22,128
if you have need to
multiple virtual drives.

98
00:05:24,503 --> 00:05:26,621
And then lastly,
we specify our networking,

99
00:05:26,621 --> 00:05:29,850
what network its gonna be connected
to if we have more than one.

100
00:05:29,850 --> 00:05:32,950
We'll take a look at the networking
side of XenServer a little bit later.

101
00:05:32,950 --> 00:05:35,170
And then when we're done,
we just finish and

102
00:05:35,170 --> 00:05:38,080
it's gonna create that virtual machine and
start the install.

103
00:05:38,080 --> 00:05:40,450
Now to save a little bit of time,
I went ahead and

104
00:05:40,450 --> 00:05:42,230
started that install before the show.

105
00:05:42,230 --> 00:05:44,250
So I've got it running right here.

106
00:05:44,250 --> 00:05:47,810
And we'll see here the install just
finished, and it's asking me to reboot, so

107
00:05:47,810 --> 00:05:50,710
I'll go ahead and let that reboot, and
we'll get a chance to see what happens.

108
00:05:50,710 --> 00:05:54,810
Now, here's where we're gonna start seeing
the big difference between a Linux install

109
00:05:54,810 --> 00:05:56,260
and a Windows install.

110
00:05:56,260 --> 00:06:00,290
With Windows, we reboot,
we get a nice graphical user interface.

111
00:06:00,290 --> 00:06:02,590
And we need to install our Xen-tools,
right.

112
00:06:02,590 --> 00:06:06,280
So you just pop in the Xen-tools disc and
a nice graphical wizard pops up and

113
00:06:06,280 --> 00:06:08,230
you walk through it and
everything's happy.

114
00:06:08,230 --> 00:06:10,890
Well, on the Linux side,
we don't have that.

115
00:06:10,890 --> 00:06:12,800
We have a script that we need to run.

116
00:06:12,800 --> 00:06:16,010
So there's a few little steps we're gonna
have to go through to get the system

117
00:06:16,010 --> 00:06:19,670
working for us as far as,
having the Xen-tools installed.

118
00:06:19,670 --> 00:06:22,210
So that's what I'm gonna take
a look at as soon as this is up.

119
00:06:22,210 --> 00:06:22,722
There we go.

120
00:06:22,722 --> 00:06:26,630
And i'm just gonna log
in with the username and

121
00:06:26,630 --> 00:06:28,560
password that was defined
during the setup.

122
00:06:30,850 --> 00:06:32,630
And we see,
can I make that a little bit bigger?

123
00:06:35,570 --> 00:06:38,180
Try and make this where we
can read it a little easier.

124
00:06:38,180 --> 00:06:38,680
There we go.

125
00:06:39,760 --> 00:06:42,120
All right, so
if I wanna install the Xen-tools.

126
00:06:42,120 --> 00:06:44,460
Well first, how do I know
the Xen-tools are not installed?

127
00:06:44,460 --> 00:06:45,280
Right?
And maybe they are.

128
00:06:45,280 --> 00:06:46,780
Maybe they were installed automatically.

129
00:06:46,780 --> 00:06:47,770
I don't know.

130
00:06:47,770 --> 00:06:51,140
Well, the way we can find out
is back here in Xen center.

131
00:06:51,140 --> 00:06:54,100
If you click on your virtual machine and
you.

132
00:06:54,100 --> 00:06:55,030
Actually, well.

133
00:06:55,030 --> 00:06:55,710
Yeah, you can see here.

134
00:06:55,710 --> 00:06:58,170
If you click on your virtual machine and
you click on general.

135
00:06:58,170 --> 00:07:01,710
In here you should see whether
Xen-tools are installed.

136
00:07:01,710 --> 00:07:05,480
See how it's got virtualization state
Xen server tools not installed?

137
00:07:05,480 --> 00:07:06,430
So right there I can see it.

138
00:07:06,430 --> 00:07:08,230
Now, I hesitated when I said that and

139
00:07:08,230 --> 00:07:10,810
that's because that's not
how I normally check.

140
00:07:10,810 --> 00:07:13,826
I normally like to check across multiple
virtual machines at the same time.

141
00:07:13,826 --> 00:07:15,620
What if you've got 50 virtual machines?

142
00:07:15,620 --> 00:07:17,810
You don't' wanna go check
each one individually.

143
00:07:17,810 --> 00:07:19,800
So you can do it from the server.

144
00:07:19,800 --> 00:07:24,710
If you go to the server and choose the
Search tab, right here in the Search tab

145
00:07:24,710 --> 00:07:29,750
you've got the used memory,
disks, and network information.

146
00:07:29,750 --> 00:07:33,280
And those are all going to be blank
if Xen-tools aren't installed.

147
00:07:33,280 --> 00:07:35,160
That's where we get that
information from so

148
00:07:35,160 --> 00:07:38,950
it's really easy to spot which virtual
machines have it, and which ones don't.

149
00:07:38,950 --> 00:07:40,490
That's what I normally do.

150
00:07:40,490 --> 00:07:41,396
Makes life a little easier.

151
00:07:41,396 --> 00:07:47,200
All right, so in my case, I don't have
it installed and I want it installed.

152
00:07:47,200 --> 00:07:49,121
So we need to get that done, all right?

153
00:07:49,121 --> 00:07:54,050
So just like in Windows, we'll go and
pop in that Xen-tools disk.

154
00:07:54,050 --> 00:07:56,710
So I'll just use the storage
drop down box there to pop in.

155
00:07:56,710 --> 00:07:58,170
I'll give it just a moment.

156
00:07:58,170 --> 00:08:01,951
And it's just giving me a little
warning there, all right.

157
00:08:01,951 --> 00:08:03,130
Got over it.

158
00:08:03,130 --> 00:08:05,320
All right so now the disk is in the drive.

159
00:08:05,320 --> 00:08:06,740
Oh the disk is not in the drive.

160
00:08:06,740 --> 00:08:07,670
Let's see what happened there.

161
00:08:13,096 --> 00:08:16,625
With Windows,
you can pop out a DVD at any time.

162
00:08:16,625 --> 00:08:19,475
WIth Linux,
the DVD will typically stay mounted.

163
00:08:19,475 --> 00:08:22,275
And when it finished the install,
it rebooted and was suppose to eject it.

164
00:08:22,275 --> 00:08:26,580
In this case, it may not have, so I have
to do a reboot before it freezes that up.

165
00:08:26,580 --> 00:08:29,388
So I'm gonna give it just a second here,
and,

166
00:08:29,388 --> 00:08:34,471
actually Let's just make sure.

167
00:08:34,471 --> 00:08:35,359
We'll do a reboot,

168
00:08:35,359 --> 00:08:38,720
that'll make sure anything I got
that's mounted will be unmounted.

169
00:08:38,720 --> 00:08:40,460
I could also go and
pull up the mount points, but

170
00:08:40,460 --> 00:08:43,820
I don't think they're gonna be there,
I think it's just stuck on the back end.

171
00:08:43,820 --> 00:08:46,840
Once you pop that disc in, though,
we'll be able to mount it and

172
00:08:46,840 --> 00:08:51,280
we'll find that there's a little script,
just bash or a .sh script

173
00:08:51,280 --> 00:08:55,250
that's right there and we can run it and
it'll take care of installing the tools.

174
00:08:55,250 --> 00:08:56,190
It's not a GUI.

175
00:08:56,190 --> 00:08:59,860
We don't get a lot of questions,
it just runs through and does the install.

176
00:08:59,860 --> 00:09:04,630
It has the Linux tools package for
Debian, Red Hat, Cent OS.

177
00:09:04,630 --> 00:09:10,520
So we'll see several packages that are all
in there, just waiting for us to use them.

178
00:09:10,520 --> 00:09:11,580
All right.

179
00:09:11,580 --> 00:09:12,930
So here, let's try this again.

180
00:09:12,930 --> 00:09:14,580
I'm gonna go ahead and pop in that disk.

181
00:09:16,140 --> 00:09:17,760
We'll give it just a moment.

182
00:09:17,760 --> 00:09:18,390
There we go.

183
00:09:20,330 --> 00:09:20,950
All right now,

184
00:09:20,950 --> 00:09:24,290
mounting a disk if you're familiar with
Linux is a pretty straightforward process.

185
00:09:24,290 --> 00:09:26,560
We need to make a directory somewhere.

186
00:09:26,560 --> 00:09:31,620
I usually use /mnt/cdrom and
I'm just gonna mount that

187
00:09:31,620 --> 00:09:35,734
device /dev/cdrom to /mnt/cdrom.

188
00:09:35,734 --> 00:09:38,140
It doesn't really matter
where you mount it.

189
00:09:38,140 --> 00:09:40,190
Just mount it somewhere
where you can get to it.

190
00:09:43,280 --> 00:09:48,970
And then, on that CD you'll find
a directory called Linux, all right.

191
00:09:48,970 --> 00:09:52,580
The Windows installers, they're all right
there in the root of the DVD, right.

192
00:09:52,580 --> 00:09:54,570
Again, Citrix knows who their market is,

193
00:09:54,570 --> 00:09:58,980
most of the people that they deal with as
customers are Windows customers because of

194
00:09:58,980 --> 00:10:02,520
Citrix XenApp and XenDesktop,
their big products.

195
00:10:02,520 --> 00:10:03,350
Those run on Windows.

196
00:10:03,350 --> 00:10:06,930
That's what they need so
that's why they cater towards Windows.

197
00:10:06,930 --> 00:10:10,040
But it doesn't mean we can't use Linux,
they've got full support for it.

198
00:10:10,040 --> 00:10:13,630
And in fact XenServer itself is
running Linux under the hood.

199
00:10:13,630 --> 00:10:16,940
So I'm just gonna change
into that directory.

200
00:10:16,940 --> 00:10:20,070
And you'll see in there install.sh, right.

201
00:10:20,070 --> 00:10:21,700
That's the installer script.

202
00:10:21,700 --> 00:10:25,930
You'll see the install packages also, you
could install these directly if you want.

203
00:10:25,930 --> 00:10:28,220
But the installer script
is a little bit easier.

204
00:10:28,220 --> 00:10:31,098
You'll see the Debian packages,
RPMs for Red Hat and Cent OS,

205
00:10:31,098 --> 00:10:32,960
they're all just sitting right there.

206
00:10:34,510 --> 00:10:37,740
And if I call that script, so
I'm just going to run install.sh.

207
00:10:37,740 --> 00:10:40,810
It's going to let me know
what it's going to do,

208
00:10:40,810 --> 00:10:44,940
it's going to install the utilities and
the XenStore and I'll just say yes.

209
00:10:44,940 --> 00:10:46,000
And there we go, right.

210
00:10:46,000 --> 00:10:48,170
Real quick, nothing too crazy there.

211
00:10:48,170 --> 00:10:52,030
It does require a reboot for them to work
so I'll go ahead and give it a reboot.

01:06:11,610 --> 01:06:16,670
ITPROTV-MYSQL01 doesn't care if
it's on server one or server two.

1347
01:06:16,670 --> 01:06:19,140
If server one fails, big deal.

1348
01:06:19,140 --> 01:06:20,450
We'll boot up on server two.

1349
01:06:20,450 --> 01:06:22,530
If server two is down,
we'll boot up on server one.

1350
01:06:22,530 --> 01:06:26,584
If they're both down,
you're probably getting some phone calls.

1351
01:06:26,584 --> 01:06:30,670
[LAUGH] So that's a bad situation, but as
long as one server's up, it'll be happy,

1352
01:06:30,670 --> 01:06:33,290
it'll run from there, and
you'll be in business, okay?

1353
01:06:33,290 --> 01:06:36,300
So that would be in the next step of
this migration is for me to go and

1354
01:06:36,300 --> 01:06:41,390
move each one of these guys over to the
shared storage, and it's gonna take time.

1355
01:06:41,390 --> 01:06:44,390
I just need to get them moved over,
and then we'll be in business.

1356
01:06:44,390 --> 01:06:47,670
And I can use the export
import function if I want, or

1357
01:06:47,670 --> 01:06:51,230
I can just use the move function that
we saw right here by right clicking.

1358
01:06:53,050 --> 01:06:56,320
All right, so we'll go ahead and do that,
and I'm not gonna move them all.

1359
01:06:56,320 --> 01:06:57,020
It'll take forever.

1360
01:06:57,020 --> 01:06:58,910
Maybe I'll start that tonight and
have it done for tomorrow.

1361
01:07:00,500 --> 01:07:04,578
As I create new virtual machines, though,
when I go to create a new virtual machine,

1362
01:07:04,578 --> 01:07:07,140
there's gonna be a slight
difference in the wizard.

1363
01:07:07,140 --> 01:07:09,959
When I go through to create one,
so I'll create another CentOS box.

1364
01:07:13,947 --> 01:07:17,553
All right?
Maybe I'm gonna whip up a FTP server, so

1365
01:07:17,553 --> 01:07:20,610
this would be be ITPROTV2-FTP01.

1366
01:07:20,610 --> 01:07:24,550
So I'm going to whip up an FTP server,
and I need to tell it what I'm going to

1367
01:07:24,550 --> 01:07:28,945
install from, and when I drop this down,
I see the SIFT's library, right there.

1368
01:07:28,945 --> 01:07:31,800
There's that ISO library.

1369
01:07:31,800 --> 01:07:33,590
Doesn't look any different to me,

1370
01:07:33,590 --> 01:07:36,250
the fact that it's attached to the pool
instead of attached to the server.

1371
01:07:36,250 --> 01:07:39,270
It just shows up right there, all right?

1372
01:07:39,270 --> 01:07:42,360
You will notice that you see
the DVD drives for the two servers.

1373
01:07:42,360 --> 01:07:44,900
So server one and
server two's DVD drives show up.

1374
01:07:44,900 --> 01:07:48,710
If I pick one of those,
I will have to start the virtual machine

1375
01:07:48,710 --> 01:07:52,140
from that physical server because I'm
trying to bond to its physical DVD drive,

1376
01:07:52,140 --> 01:07:54,510
but I'm gonna do it from the SIFT share.

1377
01:07:55,760 --> 01:07:59,000
And now, place the VM on this server.

1378
01:07:59,000 --> 01:08:02,510
I can choose a home server for
this VM and stick it on there, and

1379
01:08:02,510 --> 01:08:05,600
it will stay there, but in a cluster,
we don't normally want that.

1380
01:08:06,770 --> 01:08:09,870
We normally wanna say,
don't assign a home server.

1381
01:08:09,870 --> 01:08:12,465
In other words,
I don't care what server it boots off of.

1382
01:08:12,465 --> 01:08:13,865
Boot off of whatever works.

1383
01:08:13,865 --> 01:08:16,335
If one server doesn't work,
boot off the other one, right?

1384
01:08:16,335 --> 01:08:17,425
That's high availability.

1385
01:08:17,425 --> 01:08:19,615
That's where we start to
get that flexibility.

1386
01:08:19,615 --> 01:08:21,793
If a physical node fails,
we'll boot off the other one.

1387
01:08:23,913 --> 01:08:25,035
All right.

1388
01:08:25,035 --> 01:08:28,505
I pick my CPUs and
my memory and then storage.

1389
01:08:28,505 --> 01:08:32,405
Now, on the storage side, we need to
make sure that if we come in here and

1390
01:08:32,405 --> 01:08:36,750
like manually define storage that
we choose that shared storage.

1391
01:08:36,750 --> 01:08:37,940
If you create storage and

1392
01:08:37,940 --> 01:08:41,600
you pick some of this local storage,
you'll no longer be able to failover, and

1393
01:08:41,600 --> 01:08:44,590
in fact, it's grayed out for
me here cuz I didn't pick a home server.

1394
01:08:44,590 --> 01:08:47,260
If I'd picked a home server I
would be able to pick that, but

1395
01:08:47,260 --> 01:08:48,090
you don't want that.

1396
01:08:48,090 --> 01:08:51,208
You want it to be on that iSCSI storage so
that you can have fail over.

1397
01:08:54,292 --> 01:08:55,310
All right?

1398
01:08:55,310 --> 01:08:57,670
And now I see all those different
networks that we created.

1399
01:08:57,670 --> 01:09:03,290
I'll go attach this to to the studio
network, and we can finish it up.

1400
01:09:03,290 --> 01:09:05,772
Now I'm creating a new VM.

1401
01:09:05,772 --> 01:09:10,380
It's gonna automatically install into that
iSCSI storage, into that shared storage.

1402
01:09:10,380 --> 01:09:12,127
So this will be a cluster aware,

1403
01:09:12,127 --> 01:09:15,705
friendly, happy machine right
from the very beginning, okay?

1404
01:09:15,705 --> 01:09:17,881
Now, I didn't assign a home server, so

1405
01:09:17,881 --> 01:09:20,890
I'm kinda curious to see
where it's gonna pop up.

1406
01:09:20,890 --> 01:09:22,050
Oh, apparently we got an error.

1407
01:09:22,050 --> 01:09:22,620
Let's see what we got.

1408
01:09:23,743 --> 01:09:26,185
Internal failure, I/O control fail.

1409
01:09:26,185 --> 01:09:26,745
Interesting.

1410
01:09:26,745 --> 01:09:29,165
Link up, so it got a network error.

1411
01:09:30,705 --> 01:09:32,365
I forgot something important.

1412
01:09:32,365 --> 01:09:35,595
I mentioned how important it was to have
the same network configuration on our

1413
01:09:35,595 --> 01:09:36,475
servers.

1414
01:09:36,475 --> 01:09:40,410
Well, when we implemented this pool, I
didn't have the same configuration, did I?

1415
01:09:40,410 --> 01:09:44,689
I had partially implemented a bond on one
side, and I hadn't done that on the other,

1416
01:09:44,689 --> 01:09:47,780
and so there were kind of some
gray area stuff going on there.

1417
01:09:47,780 --> 01:09:49,270
So I really should've gone and

1418
01:09:49,270 --> 01:09:53,006
cleaned up the network configuration
before I went any further, all right?

1419
01:09:53,006 --> 01:09:56,594
Well, if you take a look at these servers,
if I take a look at ITProTV server one and

1420
01:09:56,594 --> 01:09:59,624
networking, see how I've got all
these different entries in here?

1421
01:09:59,624 --> 01:10:05,590
Some of these are ones I defined,
VLAN101, VLAN100, and so on.

1422
01:10:05,590 --> 01:10:09,230
So they're all kinda showing up in here,
the DEV network.

1423
01:10:09,230 --> 01:10:13,231
If I jump over to ITProTV server two,
and I look at the networking,

1424
01:10:13,231 --> 01:10:15,599
it's a little bit different, right?

1425
01:10:15,599 --> 01:10:19,750
I think I'm seeing one difference in here.

1426
01:10:19,750 --> 01:10:22,820
So I need to find out what
the difference is and fix it, so

1427
01:10:22,820 --> 01:10:26,160
we can kind of bounce back and
forth between these two and see.

1428
01:10:26,160 --> 01:10:27,782
It looks like it's just
that extra network adapter,

1429
01:10:27,782 --> 01:10:28,980
so that shouldn't be too big of a deal.

1430
01:10:30,000 --> 01:10:32,660
What you'll see is that you've got network
configurations under the individual

1431
01:10:32,660 --> 01:10:35,220
server, but also under the pool.

1432
01:10:35,220 --> 01:10:38,140
If I jump up to the pool,
you've got networking.

1433
01:10:38,140 --> 01:10:41,320
Now, you don't have the NIC column
where you have the physical cards

1434
01:10:41,320 --> 01:10:43,680
because the pool itself
doesn't have physical cards.

1435
01:10:43,680 --> 01:10:47,460
It just has logical ones, and so
I can see the logical networks here, and

1436
01:10:47,460 --> 01:10:50,890
I just need to clean up anything in
here that shouldn't be there, and

1437
01:10:50,890 --> 01:10:51,830
it's this network one.

1438
01:10:51,830 --> 01:10:52,850
This is the problem.

1439
01:10:52,850 --> 01:10:56,030
So I've got network one and
see how it's attached to NIC 1?

1440
01:10:56,030 --> 01:10:59,130
Well, my first server has a NIC 1.

1441
01:10:59,130 --> 01:11:00,750
My second server doesn't.

1442
01:11:00,750 --> 01:11:04,390
So I've got a disconnect there, and
that's what's gonna be causing my problem.

1443
01:11:04,390 --> 01:11:07,650
Until I correct that, I'm not gonna
be able to create new virtual

1444
01:11:07,650 --> 01:11:10,520
machines because the networks
aren't set up right.

1445
01:11:10,520 --> 01:11:12,300
So I need to go and fix that.

1446
01:11:12,300 --> 01:11:15,420
If I have a second adapter,
I need to add it to server two.

1447
01:11:15,420 --> 01:11:19,230
If I don't have an extra adapter,
I need to remove the one from server one.

1448
01:11:19,230 --> 01:11:21,623
So that means I need to physically
go over to that box and

1449
01:11:21,623 --> 01:11:24,223
pull that second card out of there,
which is kind of hard for

1450
01:11:24,223 --> 01:11:27,709
me to do with my microphone attached so
[LAUGH] maybe I'll do that after the show,

1451
01:11:27,709 --> 01:11:31,330
but that's why it's giving me that problem
with creating a new virtual machine.

1452
01:11:31,330 --> 01:11:34,928
The existing VMs are working okay because
they were created beforehand, but

1453
01:11:34,928 --> 01:11:38,690
any new one is gonna bump up against that
conflicting network configuration, so

1454
01:11:38,690 --> 01:11:40,533
that's what I'm seeing right there.

1455
01:11:40,533 --> 01:11:46,590
All right, so
I wonder if I can get around that.

1456
01:11:46,590 --> 01:11:48,091
Let me see.

1457
01:11:48,091 --> 01:11:50,291
Sometimes you can get around it.

1458
01:11:50,291 --> 01:11:53,105
If you go into the networking for
the virtual machine, and

1459
01:11:53,105 --> 01:11:56,680
you just remove all the networks Let's
see if it'll let me get around it.

1460
01:11:56,680 --> 01:12:00,520
We can remove all the network
cards from it and start it and

1461
01:12:00,520 --> 01:12:04,130
then add the one network card
that we want back again.

1462
01:12:04,130 --> 01:12:05,520
So sometimes that'll make it happy.

1463
01:12:07,860 --> 01:12:09,004
Let's see what we get there.

1464
01:12:14,101 --> 01:12:15,830
I'm starting it up here on server one.

1465
01:12:15,830 --> 01:12:16,760
We'll see if it starts.

1466
01:12:16,760 --> 01:12:20,250
If it does, then I can always just add
the individual network card back later.

1467
01:12:20,250 --> 01:12:22,370
But the real, oh, it did,
I got past it, but

1468
01:12:22,370 --> 01:12:26,020
the real fix here is going to be to go and
pull that other network adapter or get my

1469
01:12:26,020 --> 01:12:29,000
network configurations the same on the two
servers, that would have fixed this.

1470
01:12:29,000 --> 01:12:31,050
That's the right way to do it, all right?

1471
01:12:31,050 --> 01:12:33,800
But I am up so I can go ahead and
get in here and finish my install.

1472
01:12:33,800 --> 01:12:35,770
So here's my Linux install going.

1473
01:12:35,770 --> 01:12:39,830
And so I can get in here and install my
operating system, get all that set up and

1474
01:12:39,830 --> 01:12:40,990
add that network adapter.

1475
01:12:40,990 --> 01:12:41,490
Right?

1476
01:12:41,490 --> 01:12:45,020
Or if I wanna add it before the install,
I can go ahead and shut this down.

1477
01:12:45,020 --> 01:12:49,680
Because you can't add a network
adapter while it's running.

1478
01:12:51,410 --> 01:12:52,900
And so we'll shut it down.

1479
01:12:52,900 --> 01:12:55,510
It's trying to do a graceful shut down,
which it may not.

1480
01:12:55,510 --> 01:12:56,090
Oh, oh, it did.

1481
01:12:57,170 --> 01:13:03,830
And now I can add in that interface that
I want, ITProTV Studio, there we go.

1482
01:13:03,830 --> 01:13:05,300
And lets see if itll start up for
us this time.

1483
01:13:06,310 --> 01:13:10,910
If it still fails, my only choice is gonna
be to go and, yeah, I need to correct that

1484
01:13:10,910 --> 01:13:12,780
network configuration, so
thats what Ill need to do.

1485
01:13:15,730 --> 01:13:16,870
But I am.

1486
01:13:16,870 --> 01:13:21,570
All right, so that's kind of
an example of how we set up clustering.

1487
01:13:21,570 --> 01:13:22,580
There's a lot more to it.

1488
01:13:22,580 --> 01:13:24,860
I wanna talk about high availability.

1489
01:13:24,860 --> 01:13:27,540
The automatic start up
feature of failover.

1490
01:13:27,540 --> 01:13:28,880
That whole process.

1491
01:13:28,880 --> 01:13:30,870
And kinda show you guys
an example of that, but

1492
01:13:30,870 --> 01:13:35,230
as far as getting set up, there's our
steps, there's not really much to it.

1493
01:13:35,230 --> 01:13:38,000
You create the pool, you make sure
your configuration is the same

1494
01:13:38,000 --> 01:13:39,960
across your systems, and
then you're ready to rock.

1495
01:13:40,990 --> 01:13:44,970
Alright, well that's a pretty good
spot for us to wrap up right here.

1496
01:13:44,970 --> 01:13:46,960
We'll pick back up in our next episode,
and

1497
01:13:46,960 --> 01:13:49,020
go into the more advanced
side of the clustering.

1498
01:13:49,020 --> 01:13:51,460
Get that fixed and going in there.

1499
01:13:51,460 --> 01:13:52,850
It'll be a great chance to see it.

1500
01:13:53,870 --> 01:13:56,830
Really one of the best things about
XenServer is that the clustering is free.

1501
01:13:56,830 --> 01:14:00,320
It's built into the base product, so
you don't have to pay extra for it.

1502
01:14:00,320 --> 01:14:04,160
For $0 you can download XenServer,
build up a cluster, and have a nice,

1503
01:14:04,160 --> 01:14:08,440
highly available system up and running in
no time, so definitely a cool feature.

1504
01:14:09,480 --> 01:14:11,510
Alright, well I hope you
guys enjoyed the show.

1505
01:14:11,510 --> 01:14:14,850
Remember, if you had any questions
on this, live during the show,

1506
01:14:14,850 --> 01:14:18,610
you can to ITPro.tv/live, you'll see
our chat box right beneath the video.

1507
01:14:18,610 --> 01:14:21,800
You can post your questions there,
we monitor and answer during the show.

1508
01:14:21,800 --> 01:14:25,018
If you have questions after the show,
use our Q&A forums.

1509
01:14:25,018 --> 01:14:28,960
Click that Q&A link at the top of
every page at the ITProTV site,

1510
01:14:28,960 --> 01:14:30,880
and you can go in and post your questions.

1511
01:14:30,880 --> 01:14:32,160
Again, we monitor and answer.

1512
01:14:32,160 --> 01:14:34,110
We wanna make sure you guys
have the information you need,

1513
01:14:34,110 --> 01:14:36,410
so that you can be successful.

1514
01:14:36,410 --> 01:14:38,930
All right, well, like I said,
I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1515
01:14:38,930 --> 01:14:42,931
Signing off for ITProTV, I'm Don Pezet and
we'll see you next time.

1516

1

[MUSIC]

2

[SOUND]

3

[MUSIC]

4
00:00:33,686 --> 00:00:36,903
All right, good morning,
good afternoon, and good evening, and

5
00:00:36,903 --> 00:00:39,080
welcome back to another
episode of ITProTV.

6
00:00:39,080 --> 00:00:44,470
I'm your host Don Pezet, back again
with another episode of XenServer.

7
00:00:44,470 --> 00:00:47,300
I'm gonna pick up where we left
off with the last episode,

8
00:00:47,300 --> 00:00:50,390
which was we were configuring some
of the advanced settings, and

9
00:00:50,390 --> 00:00:55,410
I ended the episode by clustering
a couple of XenServers together.

10
00:00:55,410 --> 00:00:57,740
So that was kind of where we stopped.

11
00:00:57,740 --> 00:01:01,330
We had added in a extra network
card to show redundant networking,

12
00:01:01,330 --> 00:01:04,210
and that resulted in
an inconsistent cluster,

13
00:01:04,210 --> 00:01:05,770
right, we had that extra
nick sitting in there.

14
00:01:05,770 --> 00:01:07,730
So I pulled that out after the show.

15
00:01:07,730 --> 00:01:11,690
But now I wanna go into some of the more
advanced settings that deal with

16
00:01:11,690 --> 00:01:14,030
how we operate when we have a cluster,
all right?

17
00:01:14,030 --> 00:01:18,390
So I've got these two servers,
ITProTV two dash server one, and

18
00:01:18,390 --> 00:01:21,780
server two, and
they're clustered together in a pool.

19
00:01:21,780 --> 00:01:24,150
So that's what we tackled yesterday.

20
00:01:24,150 --> 00:01:27,610
Now, I want to go in an configure
some additional settings.

21
00:01:27,610 --> 00:01:30,560
There's one setting you might
have noticed was missing,

22
00:01:30,560 --> 00:01:33,400
as we were configuring our
individual virtual machines,

23
00:01:33,400 --> 00:01:37,840
when I go into a virtual machine, so
I'll take like this MySQL server here,

24
00:01:37,840 --> 00:01:41,450
when I go into the settings,
I can specify things like a home server,

25
00:01:41,450 --> 00:01:46,840
that says when this virtual machine
starts up, where does it start?

26
00:01:46,840 --> 00:01:51,290
And on this one, I've got it set
to start on ITProTV server 2, so

27
00:01:51,290 --> 00:01:53,560
when it boots up,
go ahead and start there.

28
00:01:53,560 --> 00:01:57,210
But in a high availability environment,
I may not care what server it starts on.

29
00:01:57,210 --> 00:01:58,630
I just want it to be able to start.

30
00:01:58,630 --> 00:02:03,670
So I would go and say, don't assign this
VM a home server, just start up somewhere.

31
00:02:03,670 --> 00:02:05,810
Right?
Get somewhere where you can come online,

32
00:02:05,810 --> 00:02:06,510
doesn't really matter.

33
00:02:06,510 --> 00:02:07,918
We could pick one or the other.

34
00:02:07,918 --> 00:02:10,330
If we pick a home server and
that home server is down,

35
00:02:10,330 --> 00:02:12,670
the next time we start up we'll
start up on a different server.

36
00:02:13,880 --> 00:02:19,550
But the option you won't see here
is an automatic start up setting.

37
00:02:19,550 --> 00:02:22,030
What happens if I reboot my host?

38
00:02:22,030 --> 00:02:26,780
If I reboot the host machine, what happens
to the VM's that are sitting on it?

39
00:02:26,780 --> 00:02:28,750
Well, they sit there and
they stay turned off,

40
00:02:28,750 --> 00:02:32,010
and we have to manually turn
them on after a host reboot.

41
00:02:32,010 --> 00:02:33,710
That's not ideal.

42
00:02:33,710 --> 00:02:37,050
In an environment where you want high
availability you wanna have what's called

43
00:02:37,050 --> 00:02:38,210
auto start.

44
00:02:38,210 --> 00:02:43,004
In previous versions of XenServers, I'm
running 6.2, in the 5 point versions and

45
00:02:43,004 --> 00:02:45,970
earlier, you actually had
an auto start option.

46
00:02:45,970 --> 00:02:51,470
You could say, when this host starts,
go ahead and start these VM's also.

47
00:02:51,470 --> 00:02:53,750
That option is gone in six, and

48
00:02:53,750 --> 00:02:56,510
you'll see on the internet a lot
of people upset about that.

49
00:02:56,510 --> 00:02:58,390
Well, it's not that the option is gone.

50

00:03:33,980 --> 00:03:35,010

00:06:30,380 --> 00:06:35,412

00:07:08,070 --> 00:07:09,390
If a physical node fails,

00:07:09,390 --> 00:07:13,130

00:07:30,730 --> 00:07:32,950

00:07:32,950 --> 00:07:36,190

138
00:07:36,190 --> 00:07:40,160
Both of the physical servers have

00:07:40,160 --> 00:07:42,040

00:07:42,040 --> 00:07:43,500

00:07:43,500 --> 00:07:46,350

142
00:07:46,350 --> 00:07:49,770
The RAM, what's in memory for

143
00:07:49,770 --> 00:07:51,610
is present on server one right now.

144
00:07:51,610 --> 00:07:53,010
It's got to synchronize
that to server two.

145
00:07:53,010 --> 00:07:54,255
Now that can take a moment.

146
00:07:54,255 --> 00:07:58,402
It's got to synchronize memory, and there
might be several gigs worth of RAM, and

147
00:07:58,402 --> 00:07:59,897
RAM is constantly changing.

148
00:07:59,897 --> 00:08:02,057
So performance is gonna dip.

149
00:08:02,057 --> 00:08:04,889
A little bit on the machine
while it synchronizes that RAM.

150
00:08:04,889 --> 00:08:10,363
But once it's synchronized, it can then
flip the VM over to the other server and

151
00:08:10,363 --> 00:08:13,330
you continue on with very little loss.

152
00:08:13,330 --> 00:08:17,350
In fact, what we'll normally see is

00:08:17,350 --> 00:08:21,380
three pings worse case scenario,
as we switch from one host to another.

00:08:21,380 --> 00:08:23,710

00:08:23,710 --> 00:08:27,050

00:08:34,090 --> 00:08:35,970

00:08:35,970 --> 00:08:40,480

00:08:40,480 --> 00:08:44,440

slow the system down a bit

00:08:44,440 --> 00:08:46,170
while it synchronizes RAM.

162
00:08:46,170 --> 00:08:48,760
The other reason that I'm taking such
a big hit, it normally isn't this big,

00:08:48,760 --> 00:08:50,820
is because I am on iSCSI storage.

164
00:08:50,820 --> 00:08:52,280
If I was on Fibre Channel,

165
00:08:52,280 --> 00:08:54,640
it could actually be synchronizing
a little more efficiently,

166
00:08:54,640 --> 00:08:58,580
but here the storage and the network
access are done on the same network card.

167
00:08:58,580 --> 00:09:00,910
So that creates an even bigger hit.

168
00:09:00,910 --> 00:09:04,850
But the system is being slowed right
now just to synchronize RAM, and

169
00:09:04,850 --> 00:09:07,920
once the RAM is fully synchronized,
it'll then jump.

170
00:09:07,920 --> 00:09:12,040
You'll see the virtual machine disappear

171
00:09:12,040 --> 00:09:16,870
server two, where it's now running and
happy, right, or in theory.

00:09:16,870 --> 00:09:18,170
So we'll give it a moment.

00:09:18,170 --> 00:09:20,250
I'm just kinda watching these pings.

00:09:20,250 --> 00:09:24,480
And the idea is that we should only
see like one or two pings get lost.

175
00:09:24,480 --> 00:09:25,800
Now, that virtual machine.

00:09:25,800 --> 00:09:28,460
I think it's got two gigs of RAM,

00:09:28,460 --> 00:09:30,900
I just saw my response
times go down a bit, so

00:09:30,900 --> 00:09:35,380
I think we're getting pretty close here,

00:09:35,380 --> 00:09:39,020
Now if you're an end user that's on

00:09:39,020 --> 00:09:41,030
Right?
You might notice a little performance dip

00:09:41,030 --> 00:09:43,650
but otherwise you're still
working with your documents,

00:09:43,650 --> 00:09:46,212
you don't notice that something's

00:09:46,212 --> 00:09:47,700
All right.

00:09:47,700 --> 00:09:50,250
And when the switch over does happen and
we lose one or

185
00:09:50,250 --> 00:09:54,726
two pings, most software is designed to

186
00:09:54,726 --> 00:09:55,740
It's very small, right?

00:09:55,740 --> 00:09:57,480
TCP will do re-transmits.

00:09:57,480 --> 00:09:59,820
And the end user won't

That's the really cool stuff here, is you

00:10:17,460 --> 00:10:18,290
All right.

00:10:18,290 --> 00:10:23,150
It did all that,

00:10:23,150 --> 00:10:23,960
Okay.

That's really cool stuff.

00:18:38,760 --> 00:18:41,608

00:18:59,817 --> 00:19:03,465

00:19:03,465 --> 00:19:04,949

00:19:04,949 --> 00:19:08,190
It's updating that timestamp to say,

00:19:08,190 --> 00:19:10,507
And it's doing that every two seconds.

00:19:10,507 --> 00:19:13,892
Every two seconds, it's updating

00:19:13,892 --> 00:19:19,469
Now if we have a link failure,
when this link failed back here,

00:19:19,469 --> 00:19:26,100
if we have a link failure here,

00:19:26,100 --> 00:19:28,873
Or at least it can't see

00:19:28,873 --> 00:19:31,532
how does server 1 really

00:19:31,532 --> 00:19:35,512
Server 2 might still be up, so

00:19:35,512 --> 00:19:41,190

00:19:41,190 --> 00:19:43,871

00:19:43,871 --> 00:19:47,835

00:19:47,835 --> 00:19:50,398

00:19:50,398 --> 00:19:54,815

00:19:54,815 --> 00:19:57,533

00:19:57,533 --> 00:19:58,322

00:20:06,414 --> 00:20:08,933
Server 1 shouldn't do anything,

00:20:08,933 --> 00:20:12,512
So that extra entity right there,

00:20:12,512 --> 00:20:14,661

00:20:14,661 --> 00:20:18,126
That extra repository there is

00:20:18,126 --> 00:20:20,079
not we're the cause of the problem or

00:20:20,079 --> 00:20:23,310
whether that other node is down and

00:20:23,310 --> 00:20:24,710
That's a key thing.

00:20:24,710 --> 00:20:27,582
Now you might ask yourself why do I care?

00:20:27,582 --> 00:20:28,661
Why do we even care about that?

00:20:28,661 --> 00:20:31,400
Why not just let it go ahead and

384
00:20:31,400 --> 00:20:32,310
Here's the problem.

00:20:32,310 --> 00:20:36,729
If server 1 goes active for a virtual
machine and server 2 goes active for

386
00:20:36,729 --> 00:20:41,076

if they both try and bring it active,

00:20:41,076 --> 00:20:44,450
they're both reaching out
to the storage repository.

388
00:20:44,450 --> 00:20:48,953
And they're both trying to write to
the same drive at the same time.

389
00:20:48,953 --> 00:20:52,670
And that results in almost
instantaneous corruption of the data.

390
00:20:52,670 --> 00:20:55,390
It'll corrupt the hard drives and
that VM is now dead, all right.

391
00:20:55,390 --> 00:20:56,585
You'll have to restore from backup.

392
00:20:56,585 --> 00:20:57,780
It's a mess.

393
00:20:57,780 --> 00:21:00,470
So we never want to have a scenario where

394
00:21:00,470 --> 00:21:03,800
two servers can write to
the same drive at the same time.

395
00:21:04,880 --> 00:21:07,370
That's why this file witness is so
important.

396
00:21:07,370 --> 00:21:09,790
That's why we need to have this
detection between the servers.

00:21:09,790 --> 00:21:10,620

00:38:14,020 --> 00:38:17,140
just because its plugged back in
doesnt mean it immediately goes live,

747
00:38:17,140 --> 00:38:18,300
cuz its got some problems.

748
00:38:18,300 --> 00:38:20,840
Right?
It lost connect to its storage and

749
00:38:20,840 --> 00:38:22,730
all that, so its gonna come up.

750
00:38:22,730 --> 00:38:24,960
And it's gonna do some
polling on the pool.

751
00:38:24,960 --> 00:38:27,230
It's going to say hey,
I've been gone for a minute.

752
00:38:27,230 --> 00:38:28,850
But I'm back again, what's new?

753
00:38:28,850 --> 00:38:30,028
What's exciting?

754
00:38:30,028 --> 00:38:31,690
And it's gonna connect to the pool,

755
00:38:31,690 --> 00:38:34,110
it will connect to server two,
the only other node that's there.

756
00:38:34,110 --> 00:38:38,100
And server two will say oh, while you
were gone I'm the new master, right?

757
00:38:38,100 --> 00:38:42,540
I'm running this show and these are the
virtual machines that I'm hosting now, so

758
00:38:42,540 --> 00:38:44,480
you can't host these, all right?

759
00:38:44,480 --> 00:38:47,220
But, if you wanna re-join the pool,
you can, and

760
00:38:47,220 --> 00:38:49,170
we can transition some resources to you.

761
00:38:49,170 --> 00:38:51,870
So that's what I just saw right there
is server one just changed from

762
00:38:51,870 --> 00:38:54,030
a red circle back to that blue lock.

763
00:38:54,030 --> 00:38:58,270
So it's coming back and rejoining
the pool and it's coming healthy again.

764
00:38:58,270 --> 00:38:58,790
All right.

765
00:38:58,790 --> 00:38:59,570
It's getting connected.

766
00:38:59,570 --> 00:39:02,710
For a brief moment you might have
noticed the shares down here,

767
00:39:02,710 --> 00:39:06,070
the storage repositories,
they had red circles too.

768
00:39:06,070 --> 00:39:08,860
Well, when you have
a repository like that,

769
00:39:08,860 --> 00:39:10,760
each of your nodes needs
to be able to connect.

770
00:39:10,760 --> 00:39:13,910
And if even one node can't connect,
the repository shows as failed.

771
00:39:13,910 --> 00:39:15,370
So it showed that for a moment.

772
00:39:15,370 --> 00:39:20,410
But now it's come up and it's healthy
again, now server two is part of the pool.

773
00:39:20,410 --> 00:39:24,160
Notice it did not seize
control of those VM's.

774
00:39:24,160 --> 00:39:26,310
The VM' are still up here on server two.

775
00:39:27,515 --> 00:39:30,755
Thats because server two is nice and
stable and consistent, so

776
00:39:30,755 --> 00:39:32,215
that means its just gonna sit there.

777
00:39:33,545 --> 00:39:36,355
Until we tell it to move
back over to the other side.

778
00:39:36,355 --> 00:39:38,985
So if I wanna move this one back over,
I should be able to do that now, so

779
00:39:38,985 --> 00:39:40,029
Ill go ahead and migrate it.

780
00:39:41,090 --> 00:39:42,760
And I'll send it back to server one.

781
00:39:42,760 --> 00:39:47,010
And I can do it without rebooting this
time because both servers are online,

782
00:39:47,010 --> 00:39:50,390
they can synchronize memory and
copy that stuff over and bring it healthy.

783
00:39:50,390 --> 00:39:52,900
And I can start web01 back up again also.

784
00:39:54,410 --> 00:39:57,370
And now my node will be
back to the way it was.

785
00:39:57,370 --> 00:39:59,590
So that's the cool part about HA.

786
00:39:59,590 --> 00:40:04,815
Is that HA, the High Availability, will
automatically resolve failures for you.

787
00:40:04,815 --> 00:40:07,462
Without HA, thats not going to work.

788
00:40:07,462 --> 00:40:10,109
Oh, now I get my warning.

789
00:40:10,109 --> 00:40:13,853
Now it's just warning me that I will not
be able to tolerate any further server

790
00:40:13,853 --> 00:40:17,810
failures because I had a failure, so
this is kind of a late status message.

791
00:40:17,810 --> 00:40:19,600
I haven't been looking at them, but

792
00:40:19,600 --> 00:40:24,510
you'll notice up here under System Alerts
that I've been getting alerts for

793
00:40:24,510 --> 00:40:26,580
various things and
just not paying attention to them.

794
00:40:26,580 --> 00:40:29,460
And these are each telling
me about the server failure,

795
00:40:29,460 --> 00:40:31,760
the pool master changing and so on.

796
00:40:31,760 --> 00:40:36,450
So we can see each of those little
entities in there and what is happening.

797
00:40:36,450 --> 00:40:39,545
That's how we keep kind of
record of what was going on.

798
00:40:42,064 --> 00:40:43,380
All right.

799
00:40:43,380 --> 00:40:44,610
Oh, and its not fully healthy yet.

800
00:40:44,610 --> 00:40:48,630
See, I wasnt able to start this node
because its not completely healthy yet.

801
00:40:48,630 --> 00:40:50,650
We have to wait for HA to catch back up.

802
00:40:50,650 --> 00:40:53,390
We know when HA is healthy if
we go back here and, actually,

803
00:40:53,390 --> 00:40:56,870
it does say Im already caught back up,
so it may just not be aware of it yet.

804
00:40:56,870 --> 00:41:00,820
Patience is a virtue on some of this
stuff, but yeah, so its coming healthy.

805
00:41:00,820 --> 00:41:02,840
And this ones moving,
so its healthy again.

806
00:41:03,950 --> 00:41:05,410
Yeah, so well just give
it time while it does that.

807
00:41:06,530 --> 00:41:09,890
All right, so if we want automatic
failover, we need that HAP.

808
00:41:09,890 --> 00:41:12,370
And in previous versions of
XenServer you had to pay for that.

809
00:41:12,370 --> 00:41:13,768
It was part of the Enterprise version.

810
00:41:13,768 --> 00:41:17,150
But, in 6.0 and higher, it's free.

811
00:41:17,150 --> 00:41:18,560
It's part of the base solution.

812
00:41:18,560 --> 00:41:19,400
You can do it.

813
00:41:19,400 --> 00:41:20,580
Clustering is free.

814
00:41:20,580 --> 00:41:21,480
HA is free.

815
00:41:21,480 --> 00:41:22,340
There's no reason not to do it.

816
00:41:22,340 --> 00:41:25,288
As long as you have shared storage, you
should definitely take advantage of that.

817
00:41:27,145 --> 00:41:28,022
All right,

818
00:41:28,022 --> 00:41:33,470
now what we just saw was what happens
when we have failure with HA enabled.

819
00:41:34,750 --> 00:41:39,750
If we didn't have HA enabled,
if were to go in and turn it off, right?

820
00:41:39,750 --> 00:41:43,330
And one of the servers were to fail,
the other servers wouldn't care.

821
00:41:43,330 --> 00:41:45,170
They would just ignore it.

822
00:41:45,170 --> 00:41:46,940
Big deal, so
the other server failed, right?

823
00:41:47,940 --> 00:41:52,370
If you try to take over a virtual machine
at that point, then the old server might

824
00:41:52,370 --> 00:41:55,700
still be accessing it and you can
start to run into conflicts there too.

825
00:41:55,700 --> 00:42:00,500
So under the system without HA,
it really has no way of detecting that.

826
00:42:00,500 --> 00:42:01,780
So the rule of thumb for

827
00:42:01,780 --> 00:42:06,260
me is, on a standalone server that's fine,
you just deal with it.

828
00:42:06,260 --> 00:42:11,660
But in a pool environment, in a clustered
environment like this, you always want HA.

829
00:42:11,660 --> 00:42:12,840
You always want to turn that on, so

830
00:42:12,840 --> 00:42:15,499
it's kind of like a follow up
step to turning on clustering.

831
00:42:17,060 --> 00:42:18,720
And you can turn it off whenever you want.

832
00:42:18,720 --> 00:42:22,480
If you go back up to HA,
you can just choose to disable it and

833
00:42:22,480 --> 00:42:23,180
thatll turn it off.

834
00:42:23,180 --> 00:42:25,550
It turns off almost instantly.

835
00:42:25,550 --> 00:42:28,840
Now were back to the old way
where if one server fails,

836
00:42:28,840 --> 00:42:31,035
it just takes everything with it.

837
00:42:31,035 --> 00:42:35,125
It just takes the VMs with it and they
don't failover and that's the end of it.

838
00:42:35,125 --> 00:42:37,135
So that may be what you want.

839
00:42:37,135 --> 00:42:40,695
You might want that manual
control over the failover.

840
00:42:40,695 --> 00:42:42,845
And, in that case, you wouldn't use HA.

841
00:42:42,845 --> 00:42:46,335
Or you might be using third
party software to manage this.

842
00:42:46,335 --> 00:42:48,615
Citrix actually has a set of software and

843
00:42:48,615 --> 00:42:50,970
other vendors have software
that can manage this too.

844
00:42:50,970 --> 00:42:53,970
In which case, you might not want
to use the internal HA because your

845
00:42:53,970 --> 00:42:55,900
other software is handling it for you.

846
00:42:55,900 --> 00:42:57,620
So that is another possibility.

847
00:42:59,880 --> 00:43:01,720
So that's about it for HA.

848
00:43:01,720 --> 00:43:03,540
I do have some other things
that I want to talk about but

849
00:43:03,540 --> 00:43:07,400
they don't really kind of line
up with that topic specifically.

850
00:43:07,400 --> 00:43:11,670
So, maybe we'll tackle that later.

851
00:43:11,670 --> 00:43:14,880
Another thing to mention I guess,
just before I wrap up the show, is

852
00:43:14,880 --> 00:43:19,430
when I disabled HA, so I've turned it off,
you'll see it's not currently enabled.

853
00:43:19,430 --> 00:43:25,210
If I go back to my iSCSI storage,
my HA storage has stayed, all right?

854
00:43:25,210 --> 00:43:26,520
It does stay there.

855
00:43:26,520 --> 00:43:29,440
If I turn it back on,
it can just reuse those if we want.

856
00:43:29,440 --> 00:43:30,300
Or you can delete them.

857
00:43:30,300 --> 00:43:33,830
It is safe to get rid of these now that HA
is turned off, so you can just go in and

858
00:43:33,830 --> 00:43:37,200
delete those out of there, and
they're not being used anymore.

859
00:43:37,200 --> 00:43:40,880
So they'll hang out forever if you
let them, but you can just go and

860
00:43:40,880 --> 00:43:41,559
remove them, and it's safe.

861
00:43:42,972 --> 00:43:46,180
All right, well let's go ahead and
wrap it up here then.

862
00:43:46,180 --> 00:43:50,140
We've seen clustering at this point, we've
seen high availability, so we've had that

863
00:43:50,140 --> 00:43:56,195
chance to kind of see how those work and
now we're nice, done, redundant.

864
00:43:56,195 --> 00:43:57,465
Ready to rock, right?

865
00:43:57,465 --> 00:44:00,405
The only other thing we need to do is
to take a look at some of the other

866
00:44:00,405 --> 00:44:02,145
cool features that are spread
through XenServer,

867
00:44:02,145 --> 00:44:04,475
which is what we're gonna do
in the follow-up episode.

868
00:44:04,475 --> 00:44:08,295
So stay tuned to ITProTV because we've
got more of that coming your way.

869
00:44:08,295 --> 00:44:09,335
Let me also remind you guys,

870
00:44:09,335 --> 00:44:13,110
if you have any other questions on this,
feel free to ask.

871
00:44:13,110 --> 00:44:16,250
Live during the show,
you can go to itpro.tv/live.

872
00:44:16,250 --> 00:44:18,150
You'll see the chat box
right beneath the video.

873
00:44:18,150 --> 00:44:20,100
You can post your questions there.

874
00:44:20,100 --> 00:44:22,800
We monitor and answer during the show.

875
00:44:22,800 --> 00:44:26,200
If you have questions after the show,
use the Q and A forums.

876
00:44:26,200 --> 00:44:28,929
You can jump right into Q and
A by clicking the Q and

877
00:44:28,929 --> 00:44:32,201
A link at the top of every page,
on the itpro.tv website.

878
00:44:32,201 --> 00:44:33,383
It will take you to the forums,

879
00:44:33,383 --> 00:44:36,160
post your questions there,
and we monitor and answer.

880
00:44:36,160 --> 00:44:37,120
So I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

881
00:44:37,120 --> 00:44:38,520
I'll see you next time.

882
00:44:38,520 --> 00:44:41,840
It's hard to sign out
when you've just got me.

883
00:44:41,840 --> 00:44:43,790
I'm used to having my cohost here.

884
00:44:43,790 --> 00:44:47,283
So signing out for ITProTV,
I'm Don Pezet, all by myself.

885
00:44:47,283 --> 00:44:48,535
We'll see you next time.

886
00:44:48,535 --> 00:44:58,535
[MUSIC]

episodes.title: XenServer Administration
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:10,000
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:33,028 --> 00:00:33,981
All right.
Good morning.

3
00:00:33,981 --> 00:00:34,701
Good afternoon.

4
00:00:34,701 --> 00:00:35,571
And good evening.

5
00:00:35,571 --> 00:00:38,021
And welcome back to another
episode of ITPro TV.

6
00:00:38,021 --> 00:00:39,810
I'm your host Don Pezet.

7
00:00:39,810 --> 00:00:42,600
Today with another episode of XenServer.

8
00:00:42,600 --> 00:00:44,350
One of our special series.

9
00:00:44,350 --> 00:00:46,790
Where we're not so
much focused on an exam this time.

10
00:00:46,790 --> 00:00:49,530
But just focused on how
to use the technology.

11
00:00:49,530 --> 00:00:52,600
So we've done a couple of
episodes of XenServer already.

12
00:00:52,600 --> 00:00:54,570
We've shown you guys how to install it.

13
00:00:54,570 --> 00:00:58,540
We showed how to set up a cluster and
do high availability.

14
00:00:58,540 --> 00:01:01,770
All that kind of stuff is really
things that we do in the beginning.

15
00:01:01,770 --> 00:01:04,310
When we first implemented XenServer.

16
00:01:04,310 --> 00:01:06,880
Once it's implemented,
then we just run it, right?

17
00:01:06,880 --> 00:01:09,870
We let it run and everything goes great
and we never have problems, right?

18
00:01:09,870 --> 00:01:12,580
That's our goal with any technology,
never happens.

19
00:01:12,580 --> 00:01:13,860
That's why we have jobs.

20
00:01:13,860 --> 00:01:18,230
But there are activities we need
to perform on a regular basis.

21
00:01:18,230 --> 00:01:20,460
And that's what I wanna
tackle in this episode.

22
00:01:20,460 --> 00:01:25,030
These are gonna be the ongoing activities,
just the general server administration we

23
00:01:25,030 --> 00:01:29,720
perform on a day to day basis
that is just our normal stuff.

24
00:01:29,720 --> 00:01:31,910
The stuff we do to get paid I suppose.

25
00:01:31,910 --> 00:01:35,840
So, once our servers are up and running
what are some of the things we need to do?

26
00:01:35,840 --> 00:01:39,600
Well, first off, we need to,
we need to work with the servers.

27
00:01:39,600 --> 00:01:44,060
Now, I've been using XenCenter
in all of these episodes and so

28
00:01:44,060 --> 00:01:47,230
when you've looked I've had
this graphical user interface.

29
00:01:47,230 --> 00:01:48,800
Let's see, this guy right here.

30
00:01:48,800 --> 00:01:51,350
So I've had this graphical
user interface up.

31
00:01:51,350 --> 00:01:54,730
And we've been kinda working with
the server, creating virtual machines.

32
00:01:54,730 --> 00:01:57,790
And stuff all through a nice little GUI,
all right?

33
00:01:57,790 --> 00:02:02,490
Well the GUI is nice but it makes it
very difficult to automate things.

34
00:02:02,490 --> 00:02:04,800
To automate starting up and
shutting down machines.

35
00:02:04,800 --> 00:02:08,390
Things on nature, so we don't really
have a great way to deal with that.

36
00:02:08,390 --> 00:02:10,790
The other problem with the GUI.

37
00:02:10,790 --> 00:02:15,230
It only runs on Windows and if you're
in a Windows environment, that's fine,

38
00:02:15,230 --> 00:02:16,160
what do you care, right?

39
00:02:16,160 --> 00:02:20,790
But if you are supporting Macs and
Linux desktops and so on.

40
00:02:20,790 --> 00:02:24,500
If your own desktop is a Linux desktop,
you can't run XenCenter.

41
00:02:24,500 --> 00:02:26,250
It only runs on windows.

42
00:02:26,250 --> 00:02:31,220
Well fortunately, the GUI is not the only
thing we can use to manage the server.

43
00:02:31,220 --> 00:02:36,070
Xen, underneath the hood,
is doing everything via the command line.

44
00:02:36,070 --> 00:02:39,050
There's actually a command
line utility called XE.

45
00:02:39,050 --> 00:02:41,140
And it lets us interact with XenServer and

46
00:02:41,140 --> 00:02:43,670
the Xen engine to be
able to reach in there.

47
00:02:43,670 --> 00:02:47,180
Start VM, shut off VMs, create them,
do whatever we want, all the work.

48
00:02:47,180 --> 00:02:50,890
Everything we've done in the GUI
we can do from the command line.

49
00:02:50,890 --> 00:02:51,950
It's a bit harder, right.

50
00:02:51,950 --> 00:02:53,370
You have longer commands.

51
00:02:53,370 --> 00:02:55,780
You gotta remember all these
different terms and stuff.

52
00:02:55,780 --> 00:02:58,720
So it is a little bit more difficult but
it is pretty handy.

53
00:02:58,720 --> 00:02:59,850
All right.

54
00:02:59,850 --> 00:03:02,480
When I fire up XenCenter, right.

55
00:03:02,480 --> 00:03:03,740
And I save my passwords.

56
00:03:03,740 --> 00:03:04,470
We're not seeing it here.

57
00:03:04,470 --> 00:03:06,850
But when I fire up
XenCenter it asks me for

58
00:03:06,850 --> 00:03:09,360
a user name and
password to connect to the server.

59
00:03:09,360 --> 00:03:12,150
And for the user name and
password I used root and

60
00:03:12,150 --> 00:03:16,090
the password that I set when we installed
XenCenter in the very beginning, right.

61
00:03:16,090 --> 00:03:19,890
When you installed off of that
disk it asked you for a password.

62
00:03:19,890 --> 00:03:23,330
It creates a user called root and
then it sets a password, right.

63
00:03:23,330 --> 00:03:25,730
Well from there we can get into the GUI.

64
00:03:25,730 --> 00:03:30,210
We can use that same password to connect
to the consoles of the servers themselves.

65
00:03:30,210 --> 00:03:32,820
And there's two ways
to get to the console.

66
00:03:32,820 --> 00:03:35,470
The XenServers themselves,
they're actually running Linux.

67
00:03:35,470 --> 00:03:38,740
They're running RedHat Linux,
RedHat Enterprise Linux.

68
00:03:38,740 --> 00:03:41,550
And you can get to the console
right here from the GUI.

69
00:03:41,550 --> 00:03:44,590
I know that sounds kind
of counter-intuitive but

70
00:03:44,590 --> 00:03:45,700
you can take a server.

71
00:03:45,700 --> 00:03:49,130
Like here I'll take ITPro.TV server 2 and

72
00:03:49,130 --> 00:03:51,870
you know normally we're looking
at the GUI stuff for the server.

73
00:03:51,870 --> 00:03:53,490
These screens right here.

74
00:03:53,490 --> 00:03:58,950
But if you go to the console tab,
you'll actually see the well console.

75
00:03:58,950 --> 00:04:01,190
And let me,
I'm just gonna exit out of that and

76
00:04:01,190 --> 00:04:03,110
what you'll normally see
is this message right here.

77
00:04:03,110 --> 00:04:05,360
Press enter to log in all right.

78
00:04:05,360 --> 00:04:06,740
It's authenticating you.

79
00:04:06,740 --> 00:04:09,620
Using the credentials you used
to login to [INAUDIBLE] center.

80
00:04:09,620 --> 00:04:12,420
So when you press enter,
it'll drop you right to a command prompt.

81
00:04:12,420 --> 00:04:14,840
Since I logged into XenCenter as root,.

82
00:04:14,840 --> 00:04:17,200
It's taken me to a command prompt here,
as root.

83
00:04:17,200 --> 00:04:18,430
If I do a who am I.

84
00:04:18,430 --> 00:04:20,640
I can see I am logged in as root.

85
00:04:20,640 --> 00:04:21,470
All right.

86
00:04:21,470 --> 00:04:26,540
So this is one way that I can get at
the console and start to run commands.

87
00:04:26,540 --> 00:04:30,760
And you'll see there's that XE command,
that I was talking about.

88
00:04:30,760 --> 00:04:32,650
And all of it's various modifiers.

89
00:04:32,650 --> 00:04:36,160
And there's also the XS console command,

90
00:04:36,160 --> 00:04:40,080
which is a pretty cool one because

00:36:23,950 --> 00:36:28,880

00:36:28,880 --> 00:36:34,210

00:36:34,210 --> 00:36:38,410

and now I can have an extra one, so
if I want a you know ITProTV Web04.

1005
00:57:47,316 --> 00:57:50,557
I can just go in here and
update the information.

1006
00:57:50,557 --> 00:57:54,468
I can do all sorts of things apparently.

1007
00:57:54,468 --> 00:57:56,400
Web04, there we go.

1008
00:57:56,400 --> 00:58:00,390
And I can do a fast clone or a full copy.

1009
00:58:00,390 --> 00:58:05,060
If I want the storage to be in the same
place as the original storage,

1010
00:58:05,060 --> 00:58:07,180
it can just do a disk level
copy of that storage.

1011
00:58:07,180 --> 00:58:09,980
It can actually do a snapshot and
get us running right away and

1012
00:58:09,980 --> 00:58:11,990
copy the data at a later time.

1013
00:58:11,990 --> 00:58:16,330
So it's very efficient if it's going
to the same storage repository, but

1014
00:58:16,330 --> 00:58:18,220
if it needs to go to
a different storage repository,

1015
00:58:18,220 --> 00:58:21,740
I have to do what's called a full copy,
and it'll make an exact duplicate.

1016
00:58:21,740 --> 00:58:24,530
It just takes a little
bit longer to do that.

1017
00:58:24,530 --> 00:58:27,220
In my case,
I've only got the one iSCSI storage, so

1018
00:58:27,220 --> 00:58:32,284
I'll just do a fast clone on this one,
and so I'm gonna create ITProTV Web 04.

1019
00:58:33,600 --> 00:58:35,040
All right, so it's gonna clone it.

1020
00:58:35,040 --> 00:58:38,340
See how the virtual machine is now
kinda frozen while it does that.

1021
00:58:38,340 --> 00:58:41,144
And it's cloning it and
now I've got Web 04.

1022
00:58:41,144 --> 00:58:43,064
And Web 04 is done.

1023
00:58:43,064 --> 00:58:45,839
There's no way it copied all of that hard
drive space in that amount of time and

1024
00:58:45,839 --> 00:58:46,995
it really didn't.

1025
00:58:46,995 --> 00:58:50,472
What it did is it really is treating this
like a snapshot built off of Web 05.

1026
00:58:51,545 --> 00:58:54,005
That's the quick clone option.

1027
00:58:54,005 --> 00:58:55,945
It's good for spawning machines, not so

1028
00:58:55,945 --> 00:58:58,795
great for performance unless you
just need these temporarily.

1029
00:58:58,795 --> 00:59:01,065
If this is gonna be a long term thing,

1030
00:59:01,065 --> 00:59:02,985
then we would've wanted
to have done a full copy.

1031
00:59:02,985 --> 00:59:05,105
So we'd have separate disks for each.

1032
00:59:06,175 --> 00:59:10,060
You know it's just kind of evaluating
our needs for our environment.

1033
00:59:10,060 --> 00:59:15,930
But now I can start this one up, and if I
start Web 04, and I'll start that up on,

1034
00:59:15,930 --> 00:59:21,190
we'll do server 1, when Web 04 comes up,
it should be a Linux box,

1035
00:59:21,190 --> 00:59:26,970
and it should have the web server
already installed on it, all right.

1036
00:59:26,970 --> 00:59:30,192
So that's an example of doing a copy or
a clone.

1037
00:59:30,192 --> 00:59:33,780
All right, and if I take Web 04
here it's booting up right now.

1038
00:59:33,780 --> 00:59:35,080
So we'll give it second,
I just wanna check and

1039
00:59:35,080 --> 00:59:40,680
make sure that it is actually
running the HTTPD, the web service.

1040
00:59:40,680 --> 00:59:45,150
And it should be, if I'm fast enough I can
probably see it right here at boot time.

1041
00:59:45,150 --> 00:59:47,757
Apparently I wasn't, so
I'll find it the good old fashioned way

1042
00:59:53,100 --> 00:59:54,410
And sure enough, there it is.

1043
00:59:55,420 --> 00:59:59,240
So quick easy way we can make
a true copy of a machine.

1044
00:59:59,240 --> 01:00:03,470
Some of the problems we bump into with
copies are things like IP addresses.

1045
01:00:03,470 --> 01:00:06,440
If you statically assigned an IP
address you may have duplicates.

1046
01:00:06,440 --> 01:00:08,150
If you set a host name.

1047
01:00:08,150 --> 01:00:10,900
They'll both have the same
host name cuz they are clones.

1048
01:00:10,900 --> 01:00:12,210
You cloned it, right.

1049
01:00:12,210 --> 01:00:14,110
So when I look at my
networking side of things.

1050
01:00:14,110 --> 01:00:15,300
Well it is a little bit smart.

1051
01:00:15,300 --> 01:00:19,890
It'll update the MAC addresses, so
that we don't get duplicates there.

1052
01:00:19,890 --> 01:00:21,830
So they do have different MAC addresses.

1053
01:00:21,830 --> 01:00:24,350
I'm using DHCP on these, so
they're gonna get different ones.

1054
01:00:24,350 --> 01:00:27,400
But if you had done static mappings,
you'd have the same IP address.

1055
01:00:27,400 --> 01:00:28,129
And you'd need to fix that.

1056
01:00:29,980 --> 01:00:31,670
The other option was to build a template.

1057
01:00:31,670 --> 01:00:33,040
And templates are really cool,

1058
01:00:33,040 --> 01:00:35,800
I use templates with Windows
servers all the time.

1059
01:00:35,800 --> 01:00:38,470
With Windows, if you want to whip
up a couple of web servers or

1060
01:00:38,470 --> 01:00:42,740
whatever, you can't just do a direct
clone of your original machine.

1061
01:00:42,740 --> 01:00:46,360
If you do that, they're gonna have the
same SID, the same security identifier,

1062
01:00:46,360 --> 01:00:48,580
and it causes all sorts of problems.

1063
01:00:48,580 --> 01:00:51,630
So in the Windows world we have
a utility called Sysprep, and

1064
01:00:51,630 --> 01:00:55,790
we use the Sysprep utility to
make our virtual machine generic.

1065
01:00:55,790 --> 01:00:57,700
We take away all the unique information.

1066
01:00:57,700 --> 01:01:02,560
The computer name, the IP address,
the security identifier.

1067
01:01:02,560 --> 01:01:04,190
We strip all that out, and

1068
01:01:04,190 --> 01:01:08,710
then the next time the virtual machine
boots up, it will get all new information.

1069
01:01:08,710 --> 01:01:12,848
Well what we can do is we can take a VM,
get it set up exactly the way we want,

1070
01:01:12,848 --> 01:01:16,670
and run Sysprep and
shut that machine down.

1071
01:01:16,670 --> 01:01:19,870
And once that's done,
we can convert it to a template.

1072
01:01:19,870 --> 01:01:23,510
And we can then spin up as many
machines as we want from that template.

1073
01:01:24,570 --> 01:01:26,460
The process is pretty straight forward.

1074
01:01:26,460 --> 01:01:30,030
If I take Web0,
let's see who is a Windows box.

1075
01:01:30,030 --> 01:01:30,540
I think Web 02.

1076
01:01:32,620 --> 01:01:34,841
If I take Web 02 right here,
yeah, it's a windows box.

1077
01:01:38,437 --> 01:01:42,343
And if I just get logged in to it, so what
I would do is I would get logged in, and

1078
01:01:42,343 --> 01:01:46,433
I would get it set up exactly the way that
I wanted it, you know configure whatever

1079
01:01:46,433 --> 01:01:49,957
options I needed and get things
kinda set up, and, what is it doing?

1080
01:01:52,720 --> 01:01:56,140
Seems to have kind of frozen on me.

1081
01:01:57,860 --> 01:02:01,410
Well, that's our standard
Windows environment, I suppose.

1082
01:02:01,410 --> 01:02:05,330
So [LAUGH] I guess I could try one of
these other ones, where's this guy stored?

1083
01:02:05,330 --> 01:02:10,050
Let me try this one, so
we can take one of these Windows boxes,

1084
01:02:10,050 --> 01:02:10,910
though, and we can log in.

1085
01:02:10,910 --> 01:02:12,180
And we can just run Sysprep.

1086
01:02:12,180 --> 01:02:14,110
And I guess,
if you wanna learn more about Sysprep,

1087
01:02:14,110 --> 01:02:17,220
you can always jump over to one of our
server shows and check it out there.

1088
01:02:17,220 --> 01:02:18,320
But it's a simple utility.

1089
01:02:18,320 --> 01:02:19,460
You just run it.

1090
01:02:19,460 --> 01:02:22,520
It generalizes the machine and
then shuts it down.

1091
01:02:22,520 --> 01:02:26,320
And I would show you that if this
machine was working which it is not.

1092
01:02:27,620 --> 01:02:28,723
Let's see how this other guy's doing.

1093
01:02:33,630 --> 01:02:38,163
All right, so once it's shut down, when
you right click on the VM, where I went to

1094
01:02:38,163 --> 01:02:43,170
copy VM a moment ago, you'll see another
option that says, convert to template.

1095
01:02:43,170 --> 01:02:48,337
And when you convert it to a template, now
it's ready to be cloned at your leisure.

1096
01:02:48,337 --> 01:02:53,010
And you know I'm impatient here, so
let me just shut this one back down again.

1097
01:02:53,010 --> 01:02:54,730
All right so
I'm just gonna shut it back down.

1098
01:02:54,730 --> 01:02:57,540
It does need to be shut off to
turn it into a template, and

1099
01:02:57,540 --> 01:02:59,460
yeah now it gets a little
long on the screen.

1100
01:02:59,460 --> 01:03:02,251
[LAUGH] So it does need to be shut
off to turn it into a template, but

1101
01:03:02,251 --> 01:03:06,190
once you've got it shut down you can right
click and chose Convert to Template.

1102
01:03:06,190 --> 01:03:08,740
All right, so
I'm gonna go ahead and convert it.

1103
01:03:08,740 --> 01:03:12,830
And once it's converted, see how
it's stored down here as a template.

1104
01:03:12,830 --> 01:03:17,840
And now anytime I need another web server,
I can go to new VM,

1105
01:03:17,840 --> 01:03:21,580
and when I move forward in here,
I've got that template.

1106
01:03:21,580 --> 01:03:24,350
Right there, ITProTV2-web01.

1107
01:03:24,350 --> 01:03:29,140
I can pick that template and I can spawn
a new virtual machine based of it.

1108
01:03:29,140 --> 01:03:34,790
So maybe I create ITProTV Web 05 or
6, I think is what I'm up to now.

1109
01:03:34,790 --> 01:03:36,030
And I can hit next.

1110
01:03:36,030 --> 01:03:38,270
And it's gonna build me
a new virtual machine.

1111
01:03:38,270 --> 01:03:40,680
The nice thing about
the template versus the clone

1112
01:03:40,680 --> 01:03:43,440
is that when I choose that template and
move forward,

1113
01:03:43,440 --> 01:03:46,310
I actually do have the chance to
override some of the settings.

1114
01:03:46,310 --> 01:03:49,610
I can modify things,
apparently I left xen-tools,

1115
01:03:49,610 --> 01:03:53,260
the disk in the drive when I cloned it,
so there we go.

1116
01:03:53,260 --> 01:03:55,440
I can choose to move
the storage around and stuff.

1117
01:03:55,440 --> 01:03:58,790
These were things that I was
somewhat limited on with the clone.

1118
01:03:58,790 --> 01:04:03,470
I can change CPU's and memory, and
I can change the size of the disk.

1119
01:04:03,470 --> 01:04:06,860
So we get a little bit more flexibility
than what we had on the other one.

1120
01:04:08,590 --> 01:04:12,630
And attach that network adapter,
and then we'll let it create.

1121
01:04:12,630 --> 01:04:16,220
So now it's spinning up a new VM,
based of that template from the old one.

1122
01:04:16,220 --> 01:04:17,430
Templates are pretty handy.

1123
01:04:17,430 --> 01:04:20,680
Templates are also shared
across the entire pool.

1124
01:04:20,680 --> 01:04:24,350
So I can create servers across the pool
wherever I want, all using that template.

1125
01:04:24,350 --> 01:04:26,520
It's there and it's a part of the pool.

1126
01:04:26,520 --> 01:04:30,840
So there I see Web 06 coming up right now,
built right off of that template.

1127
01:04:30,840 --> 01:04:33,690
And if I take a look at its console,
I can see its already booting up.

1128
01:04:33,690 --> 01:04:35,740
Its going along pretty quick.

1129
01:04:35,740 --> 01:04:36,960
Templates are pretty handy.

1130
01:04:36,960 --> 01:04:38,140
So just remember,

1131
01:04:38,140 --> 01:04:43,500
if we do the copy, its exact copy of the
VM, including the hardware configuration.

1132
01:04:43,500 --> 01:04:47,530
If we do a template,
we can modify the hardware configuration.

1133
01:04:47,530 --> 01:04:49,110
Tweak it and set it however we need.

1134
01:04:50,230 --> 01:04:54,420
So that's an example right there how we
can use those quick easy ways to provision

1135
01:04:54,420 --> 01:04:55,540
new machines.

1136
01:04:55,540 --> 01:04:58,550
There's several other tools that
are out there that do this, but

1137
01:04:58,550 --> 01:05:00,212
that's what's kinda built in.

1138
01:05:00,212 --> 01:05:05,340
Even the Citrix has various xen-tools that
you can use to push out new machines and

1139
01:05:05,340 --> 01:05:06,650
provision them quickly.

1140
01:05:06,650 --> 01:05:08,560
But this is a good example right here.

1141
01:05:10,090 --> 01:05:11,990
All right.
Well, I think that's about it.

1142
01:05:11,990 --> 01:05:13,510
Let me see if I missed anything.

1143
01:05:13,510 --> 01:05:15,320
Nope.
I think that's about it for

1144
01:05:15,320 --> 01:05:18,900
our general administration tasks, so it
would probably be a pretty good spot for

1145
01:05:18,900 --> 01:05:21,530
us to wrap up, I do wanna remind you guys,

1146
01:05:21,530 --> 01:05:24,530
if you have any questions on this stuff,
because it's a lot, you know,

1147
01:05:24,530 --> 01:05:27,220
there's a lot of neat things in here,
make sure you ask.

1148
01:05:27,220 --> 01:05:30,317
All right, live during the show
you can go to itpro.tv/live and

1149
01:05:30,317 --> 01:05:33,250
you'll see the chat box
right beneath your video.

1150
01:05:33,250 --> 01:05:34,520
Post your questions there.

1151
01:05:34,520 --> 01:05:36,180
We monitor and answer.

1152
01:05:36,180 --> 01:05:39,580
If we're not live when you go there,
then check out the Q and A forums.

1153
01:05:39,580 --> 01:05:41,480
You'll see a link at
the top of every page.

1154
01:05:41,480 --> 01:05:45,170
It says Q and A, click on that and
it takes you into the forums.

1155
01:05:45,170 --> 01:05:46,230
You can post your questions there.

1156
01:05:46,230 --> 01:05:47,790
And again, we monitor and answer.

1157
01:05:47,790 --> 01:05:49,810
We wanna make sure you guys get
the information that you need so

1158
01:05:49,810 --> 01:05:51,780
that you can be successful.

1159
01:05:51,780 --> 01:05:53,991
All right,
well I hope you guys enjoyed the show.

1160
01:05:53,991 --> 01:05:58,806
I'm Don Pezet, signing off for
ITProTV and I will see you next time.

1161
01:05:58,806 --> 01:06:05,889
