episodes.title: Monitoring Performance
episodes.transcript:
1
00:00:00,000 --> 00:00:07,041
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:07,041 --> 00:00:09,260
Welcome back everyone.

3
00:00:09,260 --> 00:00:13,850
In this segment, we're gonna take a look
at performance under Citrix XenServer.

4
00:00:13,850 --> 00:00:17,360
Now this is gonna be a shorter segment
thann a lot of other episodes and

5
00:00:17,360 --> 00:00:22,610
the reason is there's not a whole lot
of visibility inside a XenServer.

6
00:00:22,610 --> 00:00:27,560
It's kinda lackluster,
as far as features go, in looking at

7
00:00:27,560 --> 00:00:31,710
logging and collecting historical data,
all that other information.

8
00:00:31,710 --> 00:00:34,225
It's just not a very powerful system for
that.

9
00:00:34,225 --> 00:00:38,230
XenServer is great at some things,
performance logging is not one of them.

10
00:00:38,230 --> 00:00:41,430
At Citrix headquarters, the theory is

11
00:00:41,430 --> 00:00:45,010
you really don't need to monitor the host
as much as you do the virtual machine.

12
00:00:45,010 --> 00:00:48,840
So you should be doing your performance
monitoring inside of the VMs themselves.

13
00:00:48,840 --> 00:00:51,110
So we're relying upon Linux or Windows or

14
00:00:51,110 --> 00:00:54,550
whatever OS it is you're running in
your VMs to monitor their performance.

15
00:00:54,550 --> 00:00:58,090
On the servers side you should
really just be making sure you don't

16
00:00:58,090 --> 00:01:00,680
over allocate your resources.

17
00:01:00,680 --> 00:01:02,600
And by resources I mean the big four.

18
00:01:02,600 --> 00:01:06,920
We've got processor,
memory, hard drive, or

19
00:01:06,920 --> 00:01:11,360
disk IO really, input output, and
then network or band with, right.

20
00:01:11,360 --> 00:01:12,600
Those are our four things.

21
00:01:12,600 --> 00:01:15,930
Network, hard drive, memory, processor.

22
00:01:15,930 --> 00:01:18,700
And we just need to make sure
we don't over allocate them.

23
00:01:18,700 --> 00:01:22,660
Well, when it comes to things like memory,
that's pretty easy to keep track of.

24
00:01:22,660 --> 00:01:25,330
If I have five virtual machines and

25
00:01:25,330 --> 00:01:29,280
I give each one two gigs of RAM,
that's ten gigs of RAM.

26
00:01:29,280 --> 00:01:33,860
I need to have at least ten gigs available
on the host OS or I'm gonna have issues.

27
00:01:33,860 --> 00:01:36,596
Right?
And if we use dynamic RAM, then you could

28
00:01:36,596 --> 00:01:40,308
say I have ten gigs allocated but
only eight gigs in the server.

29
00:01:40,308 --> 00:01:43,394
You can do things like that but
it hurts performance right off the bat so

30
00:01:43,394 --> 00:01:45,707
it's really only in testing and
lab environments.

31
00:01:45,707 --> 00:01:48,866
For CPU, we have to think about cores.

32
00:01:48,866 --> 00:01:53,766
If I have eight virtual machines and
they all have one VCPU, well,

33
00:01:53,766 --> 00:01:55,702
then there's eight VMs.

34
00:01:55,702 --> 00:01:57,825
That means I'm gonna need eight cores so

35
00:01:57,825 --> 00:02:01,160
that each of them can have
their one CPU access, right.

36
00:02:01,160 --> 00:02:04,070
If I have more, I can do that, but
now there'll be contention for

37
00:02:04,070 --> 00:02:05,600
access to those CPUs.

38
00:02:05,600 --> 00:02:08,820
So that's really all we need
on the performance side but

39
00:02:08,820 --> 00:02:10,640
that doesn't mean there isn't
anything we can look at.

40
00:02:10,640 --> 00:02:13,370
There are some neat things and I'm
gonna show you right here in XenCenter.

41
00:02:13,370 --> 00:02:17,025
I'm looking at my little server cluster
that we set up in an earlier episode, and

42
00:02:17,025 --> 00:02:18,547
so I've got my servers laid out.

43
00:02:18,547 --> 00:02:22,916
And one of the nice things you'll notice
is that when you go to look at the server,

44
00:02:22,916 --> 00:02:24,970
so I'm just right here on my pool, and

45
00:02:24,970 --> 00:02:27,431
I can see the servers
that are underneath it.

46
00:02:27,431 --> 00:02:30,890
And you get these nice
little charts that show you,

47
00:02:30,890 --> 00:02:34,060
you can see right here ITPROTV2-SERVER2.

48
00:02:34,060 --> 00:02:35,900
That's my host.

49
00:02:35,900 --> 00:02:39,217
Has 8 gigs of RAM in it and
I've allocated 5 gigs out.

50
00:02:39,217 --> 00:02:41,893
So I can see how much RAM I'm using, and

51
00:02:41,893 --> 00:02:45,139
then beneath that I can
see my individual VMs and

52
00:02:45,139 --> 00:02:50,436
I can see that I've given 2 gigs of RAM
to one VM and 2 gigs of RAM to the other.

53
00:02:50,436 --> 00:02:55,475
And inside of them they're
using like 440 and 499 megs.

54
00:02:55,475 --> 00:03:00,484
So seeing that right in there,
I also see the CPUs,

55
00:03:00,484 --> 00:03:05,857
I've given one CPU to Web 02 and
two CPUs to Web 06.

56
00:03:05,857 --> 00:03:08,894
Now I've only got two CPUs
in this particular host, so

57
00:03:08,894 --> 00:03:13,714
it shows right right there that I've got
two CPUs, so I've over-allocated my CPUs,

58
00:03:13,714 --> 00:03:16,885
but that's okay because if
you look at the utilization,

59
00:03:16,885 --> 00:03:19,752
these guys are sitting here
doing next to nothing.

60
00:03:19,752 --> 00:03:22,829
There sitting at 0% CPU, 1% total.

61
00:03:22,829 --> 00:03:27,765
So we can use this screen right here,
just our general overview,

62
00:03:27,765 --> 00:03:33,232
out search screen to see basic
things like processor and memory.

63

00:17:23,290 --> 00:17:24,610
